channel.title: Form Submission {Help} [HTML]
channel.description: So I don't know if you guys saw my other post about that horrendious site I'm working on, but I need to re-do the form submission section. I've never really worked with them so I don't know what I should change (Aside from deprecated tags and use better spacing etc). Here's what I'm working with: [url=http://pastebin.com/Uhyzt2h9]Form Submission - Pastebin.com[/url] Yes, JUST the form submission is 30k characters... :(

item.title: Form Submission {Help} [HTML]
item.dc:creator: @sk8rdude461 sk8rdude461
item.description:
@sk8rdude461 wrote:

[quote=“RSCShadow, post:28, topic:476205”][quote author=sk8rdude461 link=topic=594354.msg4188849#msg4188849 date=1356568419]

I know I was just using it as an example of validation and the label tag. Any text corresponding to a viewable input should probably have a label though.

[img]http://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3b/Paris_Tuileries_Garden_Facepalm_statue.jpg/300px-Paris_Tuileries_Garden_Facepalm_statue.jpg[img]

I didn’t even know of the label tag… I feel stupid now. I was using

to label everything…
[/quote]Always look for more specific elements to describe the document before going to the more generic.[/quote]
Told you I didn’t know much about forms

Read full topic

item.title: Form Submission {Help} [HTML]
item.dc:creator: @RSCShadow RSCShadow
item.description:
@RSCShadow wrote:

[quote=“sk8rdude461, post:25, topic:476205”][quote author=RSCShadow link=topic=594354.msg4188839#msg4188839 date=1356567362]
You should try to be practising semantic HTML in your code. So, instead of a span, use a to describe the input along with the for attribute with the same id as the input. This will describe your intents a lot more clearly and is great for user experience because clicking the label focuses the input. I also recommend some of the new HTML5 input attributes for client side validation.

<label for="username">Username</label>
<input type="text" name="username" id="username" required="required" pattern="[A-Za-z]{20}" title="Please only use A-Z in your username." maxlength="20" />

[/quote]
Honestly, that span tag isn’t needed, as I’m not using it. I just left it there, for well idk.
But I do have some of the newer Form validation tags in there. It’s a contact form, so user names wouldn’t be wanted.[/quote]I know I was just using it as an example of validation and the label tag. Any text corresponding to a viewable input should probably have a label though.

Read full topic

So, instead of a span, use a to describe the input along with the for attribute with the same id as the input. This will describe your intents a lot more clearly and is great for user experience because clicking the label focuses the input. I also recommend some of the new HTML5 input attributes for client side validation.

<label for="username">Username</label> <input type="text" name="username" id="username" required="required" pattern="[A-Za-z]{20}" title="Please only use A-Z in your username." maxlength="20" /> [/quote]
Honestly, that span tag isn’t needed, as I’m not using it. I just left it there, for well idk.
But I do have some of the newer Form validation tags in there. It’s a contact form, so user names wouldn’t be wanted.

item.title: Form Submission {Help} [HTML]
item.dc:creator: @RSCShadow RSCShadow
item.description:
@RSCShadow wrote:

[quote=“sk8rdude461, post:23, topic:476205”][quote author=RSCShadow link=topic=594354.msg4188833#msg4188833 date=1356566564]

[quote author=sk8rdude461 link=topic=594354.msg4188827#msg4188827 date=1356565978]

Anyone know how to center these the tag?
-it has like 30 options in it too…
[/quote]Depends on the context. Where are they currently? What style options are applied to them now? You need to give us more information. Show us the CSS.

There’s no style on them what so ever. It’s just , the options, and the ending
I tried the margin-right(left):0 auto;
[/quote]In order for margin centring to work you need to apply a width to the element. I’m pretty sure you’d also need to make it into a block element.

Ah I see.
Ehh, the form may not need it, might make things look funny if I did make it centered.

[code]

First Name:

[code] Should I add correct syntax to that or no? [/code][/quote]You should try to be practising [url=http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Semantic_HTML]semantic HTML[/url] in your code. So, instead of a span, use a to describe the input along with the for attribute with the same id as the input. This will describe your intents a lot more clearly and is great for user experience because clicking the label focuses the input. I also recommend some of the [url=http://www.the-art-of-web.com/html/html5-form-validation/]new HTML5 input attributes[/url] for client side validation. 
<label for="username">Username</label>
<input type="text" name="username" id="username" required="required" pattern="[A-Za-z]{20}" title="Please only use A-Z in your username." maxlength="20" />

Read full topic

item.title: Form Submission {Help} [HTML]
item.dc:creator: @RSCShadow RSCShadow
item.description:
@RSCShadow wrote:

[quote=“sk8rdude461, post:17, topic:476205”][quote author=RSCShadow link=topic=594354.msg4188771#msg4188771 date=1356561634]
You can use something like Live HTTP Headers to see what the browser is sending to the non-existent server.

EDIT:

Things like this are what confuses me:

[code]

[/code] Is that needed or what? I know it redirects to thankyou.html, but it's self ending.. [/quote]Those are sent to the server as normal values. It doesn't redirect client side, it probably tells the server where to redirect the person who submitted the form (supposedly, it might not, who knows).

That’s the thing. The submit button is at the bottom; and is titled “please call me”.
I don’t know if it’s needed or not[/quote]Well like I said we can’t help you until you tell us what the server needs. All forms need a submit button to send the data to a server but the names depend on the server implementation.

Read full topic

EDIT:

[quote author=sk8rdude461 link=topic=594354.msg4188769#msg4188769 date=1356561547]
Things like this are what confuses me:

[code]

[/code] Is that needed or what? I know it redirects to thankyou.html, but it's self ending.. [/quote]Those are sent to the server as normal values. It doesn't redirect client side, it probably tells the server where to redirect the person who submitted the form (supposedly, it might not, who knows).[/quote] That's the thing. The submit button is at the bottom; and is titled "please call me". I don't know if it's needed or not

Read full topic

item.title: Form Submission {Help} [HTML]
item.dc:creator: @justaguy justaguy
item.description:
@justaguy wrote:

[quote=“sk8rdude461, post:14, topic:476205”][quote author=justaguy link=topic=594354.msg4188766#msg4188766 date=1356561374]
You could always split up this huge form into different sections like how Runescape did it for their registration pages in 2007(?) and prior. Still, you’re going to need forms.

PS: I can only assume it’s as big as I think it is because the pastebin text is really all over the place.
[/quote]
Probably is.
Do you know how you could check what it submits? Or to see what values are sent?
And I don’t know what runescape did when they spit the registration into parts, or at least, don’t know what you mean by it.[/quote]

I’m guessing you can’t check with PHP so RSCShadow’s post will do.

Runescape basically had: one page for checking the age, another one for terms and conditions, player registration, and so on. It is the same PHP file but with some code to make it have the form sequenced in “steps.”

Read full topic

[/code] Is that needed or what? I know it redirects to thankyou.html, but it's self ending..[/quote]Those are sent to the server as normal values. It doesn't redirect client side, it probably tells the server where to redirect the person who submitted the form (supposedly, it might not, who knows).

item.title: Form Submission {Help} [HTML]
item.dc:creator: @sk8rdude461 sk8rdude461
item.description:
@sk8rdude461 wrote:

[quote=“justaguy, post:12, topic:476205”]You could always split up this huge form into different sections like how Runescape did it for their registration pages in 2007(?) and prior. Still, you’re going to need forms.

PS: I can only assume it’s as big as I think it is because the pastebin text is really all over the place.[/quote]
Probably is.
Do you know how you could check what it submits? Or to see what values are sent?
And I don’t know what runescape did when they spit the registration into parts, or at least, don’t know what you mean by it.

RSCShadow:

Why would you need alternatives to begin with? I don’t think you understand how forms work. The only thing required for a submission is a submit button but the server could be expecting other data as well. We don’t know how your server is set up so it wouldn’t be possible to help any further.

I’ve contacted him to see what happens when you submit the form. Till then I don’t know. 'less there’s another way to see what it sends

Things like this are what confuses me:

[code]

[/code] Is that needed or what? I know it redirects to thankyou.html, but it's self ending..

Read full topic

item.title: Form Submission {Help} [HTML]
item.dc:creator: @sk8rdude461 sk8rdude461
item.description:
@sk8rdude461 wrote:

[quote=“RSCShadow, post:4, topic:476205”][quote author=sk8rdude461 link=topic=594354.msg4188730#msg4188730 date=1356559765]

What are you asking for specifically? Saying “I need help” and posting a giant block of text gets us nowhere.

[quote author=sk8rdude461 link=topic=594354.msg4188721#msg4188721 date=1356558636]but I need to re-do the form submission section.
[/quote]
I didn’t say anything on what I need help with. At all…
Lol.
I don’t know what you need for form submissions, and if there’s a better alternative out there.
[/quote]Maybe you should read your topic [quote=Your Topic]Form Submission {Help} [HTML][/quote]

What sort of form submission is it? What kind of data are you sending? What sort of server is receiving it? I’m not going to look through your entire code and rewrite something for you. Figure out what you need and ask for more specific help if you need it. There are no alternatives for in HTML.[/quote]
Dude, I don’t even know. I didn’t make it. I’m re-writing it for a customer.

Read full topic
